they kind of do that much they really get smart if you connect them so if you
expose their their data and their configuration interfaces and control
interfaces over network then they can talk to each other and they can
coordinate but then they can get really smart if you connect them to the Internet and when you connect those
devices to the Internet then of course you need to rethink the design because
devices that were conceived before for safety and security critical
applications now also need to take into account the risk of being attacked from the internet so we wanted to see
how this is done in current devices and for this we did a large-scale study on
an embedded firmware okay but before we
we go into the problems and design of the system let's first look at some

backdoor which is a nice feature and it was actually used in d-link tools

second example is a printer this was work done by Andre Christine he looked

listening to the room and first effectively transforming the telephone into a bug that is inside your office

have already been several researchers that showed that if you can hook into the onboard diagnosis system which is

activate your the brake while you're driving on the highway and okay this

that each of the analysis that was done there is is individual analysis and
there is huge manual effort into it in each of these analysis and if you want
to do this at large scale this this is not feasible but our goal was to do a

at what approaches no stop so what why do we have problems doing a large-scale
analysis on farmer so there is a lot of heterogeneity in embedded systems first
the hardware platforms are different it's very different what input would output you have sometimes you don't have text input output for example you just
have sensors remote command something like this also how Hardware appears inside to the
firmware is very different where there's where it's mapped in address space then
CPU architectures are vastly different there is our MIPS sh4 and a tons of
other systems operating systems in embedded are much more diverse than in
the PC settings you have vxworks Q and X
several real-time operating systems and also library hardware abstraction
libraries that are not real operating systems this on the one hand side then
also the uses of embedded systems are very different how they what they want
to do with the embedded system and the requirements they have so yeah the
driving track is much different from switching your television and finally
the security goals of embedded devices are very different the dishwasher of my grandmother doesn't need to have the
same security as a PLC in a nuclear power plant so why does manual analysis
not work in this heterogeneous setting because for each of these very different systems we need to find and download
former then once we have obtained the firmware we need to unpack the firmware
and then perform some analysis on it and then we will discover some box maybe and
in most cases we will probably rediscover bugs that have been discovered in other devices before so we
looked at some previous approaches on that there was one by boyanov for analyzing embedded web
interfaces and he used real devices which of course gives very accurate
results but then on the other hand it does not scale well because you need to buy all those devices which costs money
then afterwards you need to maintain them and if for example one device gets stuck you need to reboot it so a lot of
effort not feasible for our approach another
port has been to scan devices on the Internet for example a large scale
testing has been done by an cui in 2010 but the problem if you do this is you
can only scan for already known vulnerabilities and you have a black box
approach this means if you send an exploit to one device then it might not respond anymore but it might not respond
anymore because it has crashed because your your packets have been detected by
an intrusion detection system and you're blocked now or maybe the device was just
switched off so you cannot really tell more about what is going on if you do
this approach and also testing on other people's devices is perceived as
ethically questionable for example the internet census of 2012 where one guy
uploaded code on thousands of embedded systems then used this code to do a port
scan on the complete Internet and afterwards uninstall his code is probably too intrusive because you
cannot just own another device and install code on it so what is our
approach well first we want to collect a large number of former images then we

want to correlate across firmer to see which one which one or abilities reappear between firmware the advantages
of this approach is that first compared to what I told before the there is no

next problem and there is a solution for that it's called file carving and file
carving just means that you go at every offset of the file and you try each and
Pecha that you have at this offset but of course you need to have a good
heuristics that tells you when to stop because if you go to if you try every offset of the file then if you have a
compression format that is quite compact then it will still start extracting something which afterwards turns out to
be garbage but you don't know this automatically and there are there were
existing tools for that we looked at bin wok which at that time didn't have a

the analysis cloud consists of a master node this master node takes the firmware
and distributes it to one of the worker nodes the worker nodes do the actual
work meaning they unpack they do the static analysis and they calculate the
fuzzy hashes of all the files apart from that there's one special note the password hash cracker which takes all
the password hashes that were found inside images so normally in a New York
